For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles.     "output": "Thought: (\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to merge \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d and \u201centanglement witness\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible target:\n    1) A high\u2010dimensional entanglement\u2010swapping network (qutrits or ququarts) that immediately runs a linear\u2010optical multipartite entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped pair\u2014i.e. integrate the swapping subnetwork and the on\u2010line witness\u2010measuring subnetwork in one unified design.\n    2) A teleportation\u2010based implementation of a small quantum algorithm (e.g. a two\u2010bit parity or Deutsch\u2013Jozsa oracle) where, after the distributed gate sequence is applied via entanglement\u2010swapping links, an entanglement witness circuit tests the genuine multipartite correlations generated by that algorithm.\n    3) A measurement\u2010based computation on a small cluster (say four modes) where the cluster implements a simple algorithmic unit (like a controlled\u2010phase gate plus Hadamard) followed by an entanglement witness evaluation on the leftover modes to certify that the one\u2010way QC resource was genuinely entangled.\n  Step 2: Quick novelty and Pytheus feasibility check:\n    1) Novel: no existing pytheus target mixes high\u2010D swapping with witness. Feasible: uses only linear optics, probabilistic pairs, detectors.\n    2) Overlaps too much with teleportation\u2010gate examples and quantum computing focus (forbidden).\n    3) Tropes of cluster\u2010state generation (forbidden: state generation).\n  Step 3: Pick idea #1 as most novel and Pytheus\u2010feasible.\n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no current pytheus experiments combine multilevel entanglement swapping and a built\u2010in entanglement\u2010witness measurement\u2014all in one linear\u2010optical network design\u2014and it opens a family of designs for different dimensions and different witness criteria.\n  Step 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires specifying an abstract target that fuses a qutrit\u2010swapped Bell pair with the subsequent projection patterns that realize a standard linear\u2010optical entanglement witness; Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter layouts, ancilla modes and detectors accordingly without invoking state\u2010generation hardware details or feedback control.\n)\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nWe propose a new class of quantum\u2010optical network experiments that 1) performs entanglement swapping on two qutrit Bell pairs via ancillary photons, and 2) immediately runs a linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped output\u2014integrating distribution and certification of high\u2010dimensional entanglement in one architecture.  \n\nExplanation and visualization:  \n - Sources: six single\u2010photon qutrit\u2010pair emitters generating two Bell\u2010like qutrit pairs (modes A\u2013C and D\u2013F).  \n - Swapping subnetwork: Charlie uses beam splitters and ancillary detectors (modes G\u2013L) to perform a generalized Bell\u2010measurement on C and D, heralding entanglement between A and F in the three\u2010dimensional space.  \n - Witness subnetwork: immediately after heralding, modes A and F are fed, together with two fresh ancilla photons (modes M,N), into a small interferometric circuit that implements the standard qutrit entanglement witness  \n    W = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2212 |\u03a8\u208a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a8\u208a|  \n  via multiport beam splitters and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nEntanglement-Fano Interferometry via Three-Channel Heralded Swaps in a Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a discrete-vs-continuum Fano-resonance experiment between distant nodes A and C in which the two-photon Bell-state amplitude from a direct Bell-pair source coherently interferes with amplitudes generated by successive two-hop (via B) and three-hop (via D\u2192E) heralded entanglement swaps, with static polarization phase shifts \u03c6\u2082 and \u03c6\u2083 controlling the interference.  The resulting asymmetric coincidence fringe at A\u2013C reproduces the characteristic Fano line shape of a micro-ring resonator in a purely linear, static network\u2014implementable in Pythueus using only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, abstract phase shifters, Bell measurements, and photon-number-resolving detectors.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \n\u201cCyclic-Graph Teleportation with Passive Pauli Cancellation and Measurement-Controlled Phase Gate\u201d\n\nAbstract  \nWe implement a static linear-optical protocol that teleports an unknown qubit from Alice (mode 0) to Bob (mode 3) by entangling four probabilistic Bell pairs into a cycle graph, passively canceling all Pauli by-products and embedding a measurement-controlled Z-rotation on the teleported state without any active feed-forward. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a new class of quantum\u2010optical network experiments that 1) performs entanglement swapping on two qutrit Bell pairs via ancillary photons, and 2) immediately runs a linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped output\u2014integrating distribution and certification of high\u2010dimensional entanglement in one architecture.  \n\nExplanation and visualization:  \n - Sources: six single\u2010photon qutrit\u2010pair emitters generating two Bell\u2010like qutrit pairs (modes A\u2013C and D\u2013F).  \n - Swapping subnetwork: Charlie uses beam splitters and ancillary detectors (modes G\u2013L) to perform a generalized Bell\u2010measurement on C and D, heralding entanglement between A and F in the three\u2010dimensional space.  \n - Witness subnetwork: immediately after heralding, modes A and F are fed, together with two fresh ancilla photons (modes M,N), into a small interferometric circuit that implements the standard qutrit entanglement witness  \n    W = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2212 |\u03a8\u208a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a8\u208a|  \n  via multiport beam splitters and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While integrating high-dimensional entanglement swapping and an on-the-fly qutrit entanglement witness into one static network is a nice engineering touch, both primitives\u2014the generalized Bell swap for two qutrit Bell pairs (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical implementations of entanglement witnesses or Schur analyzers\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them in a single circuit does not introduce a fundamentally new network primitive or reveal a novel quantum effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification."

A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to merge \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d:\n  1) A single joint measurement that both swaps high\u2010D entanglement and evaluates a witness at once\u2014i.e. a \u201cSwap\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d  \n  2) A teleportation\u2010based implementation of a two\u2010qubit oracle (Deutsch\u2013Jozsa) where the oracle is applied via entanglement swapping, followed by an in\u2010line witness\u2010measurement of the output entanglement.  \n  3) A small nonadaptive linear-optical phase-estimation circuit (a one\u2010qubit QFT) built into an entanglement\u2010swapping chain, with a final witness step certifying both algorithmic coherence and entanglement.  \nStep 2: Quick feasibility & novelty:\n  1) No Pytheus experiment so far fuses swapping and witness into one measurement block. It stays within linear optics + probabilistic sources + detectors.  \n  2) This leans too far toward a computing task (DJ algorithm) and would need feed-forward to succeed deterministically\u2014Pytheus cannot handle that.  \n  3) Small QFT on one qubit is trivial and effectively state generation; also borderline computing.  \nStep 3: The \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d (idea #1) is both novel and fully implementable by Pytheus.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus targets define a multiport that simultaneously performs entanglement swapping and extracts an entanglement\u2010witness expectation in a single nonadaptive measurement. It elevates the Bell\u2010measurement block to a richer primitive that both distributes and certifies entanglement.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses abstract photonic modes, beam splitters, phase shifters, ancillary photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors; it does not require feedback or physical encodings. Pytheus can optimize the unitary transformation and ancilla pattern to realize both the swapping projector and the witness operator in one fused network.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nWe propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Output:\n      \u2013 A click on the heralding subset signals that A\u2009&\u2009F are entangled  \n      \u2013 Simultaneous click\u2010pattern on the \u201cwitness\u201d detectors gives the numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Four-Party GHZ Entanglement-Swapping Star with 3\u21921 Network Steering\n\nAbstract: We implement a single-step four-photon GHZ entanglement-swapping star that fuses four independent probabilistic Bell-pair sources at a central station via a linear-optical 4-photon GHZ projector to realize the target 4-party GHZ resource. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating high-dimensional entanglement swapping and an on-the-fly qutrit entanglement witness into one static network is a nice engineering touch, both primitives\u2014the generalized Bell swap for two qutrit Bell pairs (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical implementations of entanglement witnesses or Schur analyzers\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them in a single circuit does not introduce a fundamentally new network primitive or reveal a novel quantum effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Output:\n      \u2013 A click on the heralding subset signals that A\u2009&\u2009F are entangled  \n      \u2013 Simultaneous click\u2010pattern on the \u201cwitness\u201d detectors gives the numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While integrating qutrit entanglement swapping with an on-the-fly entanglement witness is a nice engineering touch, both ingredients\u2014the generalized qutrit Bell-measurement and static linear-optical entanglement-witness circuits\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them into one bigger multiport does not introduce a new fundamental network primitive or reveal an unexpected quantum effect; it amounts to \u201cdo a swap then do a witness\u201d rather than a genuinely unified operation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both high-dimensional swapping (cf. \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical entanglement witnesses/Schur analyzers already exist. To reach PRL level, you\u2019d need a nontrivial fusion that cannot be decomposed into separate swap+certify steps\u2014e.g. a single joint measurement with fewer resources or novel interference that intrinsically couples distribution and certification."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"complex quantum algorithm\" and \"entanglement witness\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to merge \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d:\n  1) A single joint measurement that both swaps high\u2010D entanglement and evaluates a witness at once\u2014i.e. a \u201cSwap\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d  \n  2) A teleportation\u2010based implementation of a two\u2010qubit oracle (Deutsch\u2013Jozsa) where the oracle is applied via entanglement swapping, followed by an in\u2010line witness\u2010measurement of the output entanglement.  \n  3) A small nonadaptive linear-optical phase-estimation circuit (a one\u2010qubit QFT) built into an entanglement\u2010swapping chain, with a final witness step certifying both algorithmic coherence and entanglement.  \nStep 2: Quick feasibility & novelty:\n  1) No Pytheus experiment so far fuses swapping and witness into one measurement block. It stays within linear optics + probabilistic sources + detectors.  \n  2) This leans too far toward a computing task (DJ algorithm) and would need feed-forward to succeed deterministically\u2014Pytheus cannot handle that.  \n  3) Small QFT on one qubit is trivial and effectively state generation; also borderline computing.  \nStep 3: The \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d (idea #1) is both novel and fully implementable by Pytheus.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus targets define a multiport that simultaneously performs entanglement swapping and extracts an entanglement\u2010witness expectation in a single nonadaptive measurement. It elevates the Bell\u2010measurement block to a richer primitive that both distributes and certifies entanglement.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses abstract photonic modes, beam splitters, phase shifters, ancillary photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors; it does not require feedback or physical encodings. Pytheus can optimize the unitary transformation and ancilla pattern to realize both the swapping projector and the witness operator in one fused network.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nWe propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both high-dimensional swapping (cf. \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical entanglement witnesses/Schur analyzers already exist.     "output": "Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to merge \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible target:\n    1) A single linear\u2010optical network that teleports a two\u2010qubit CNOT gate between remote photons (via entanglement swapping) and in the same measurement solves a Bell\u2010inequality\u2010type entanglement witness on the output\u2014i.e. a \u201cCNOT\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d  \n    2) A network that implements a small phase\u2010estimation subroutine (a three\u2010mode Fourier transform) on an entangled pair and then projects onto a multipartite witness operator in one fused measurement.  \n    3) A teleportation\u2010based implementation of a two\u2010bit parity function (algorithmic) on teleported qubits, followed immediately by a generalized entanglement witness to certify the resource was indeed entangled during the computation.  \n  Step 2: Feasibility & novelty check:\n    1) Heralded CNOT gates have been designed, and entanglement\u2010witness measurements too\u2014but no one has asked Pytheus to design a single network that both implements a nontrivial two-qubit algorithm (CNOT) via teleportation and simultaneously reads out an entanglement witness, all in one block. It uses only linear optics + pair\u2010sources + ancilla + detectors, so it is in Pytheus\u2019s sweet spot.  \n    2) Phase estimation network is effectively state generation of a small Fourier state, too close to state prep.  \n    3) Parity is trivial, not a \u201ccomplex\u201d enough algorithmic primitive.  \n  Step 3: Select idea #1: the CNOT\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target fuses a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate teleportation (CNOT) with an in\u2010line entanglement witness measurement into one nonadaptive linear\u2010optical network. This opens a family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d building blocks for photonic quantum networks.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: It invokes only abstract beam\u2010splitter arrays, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, ancilla photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize the multiport unitary so that one subset of detectors heralds a successful teleported CNOT, while another subset\u2019s coincidence statistics directly give \u27e8W\u27e9 for a chosen witness (e.g. CHSH witness) on the post-CNOT output. There is no feedback control, no forbidden state\u2010generation hardware, and everything is cast as \u201cdesign a network + measurement\u201d\u2014exactly what Pytheus is built for.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cCNOT-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d as a new Pytheus target: one linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell-pair sources (four photons) plus ancillas\u2014simultaneously  \n  (i) teleports a two-qubit CNOT gate between the remote qubits via an entanglement-swapping subnetwork, and  \n  (ii) in the very same interferometer and detection event, implements an entanglement witness measurement (e.g. CHSH-type or stabilizer witness) on the two output qubits.  \n\nGeneral structure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources:  \n      \u2013 S\u2081 emits photons in modes A,C (Bell pair 1)  \n      \u2013 S\u2082 emits photons in modes D,F (Bell pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla single photons in modes G,H for the CNOT teleportation gadget  \n      \u2013 (Optionally) Ancilla modes I,J for the witness block  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U mixes modes C,D,G,H (to realize the teleportation\u2010CNOT projector) and then mixes A,F,I,J (to realize the witness projector W).  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2081\u2026Det\u2096} record the heralding click pattern of the teleportation gadget \u2192 flags when CNOT has been applied to A\u2192F.  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2096\u208a\u2081\u2026Det\u2099} record the witness measurement outcomes on A,F & ancillas \u2192 their coincidence probabilities yield Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}^out].  \n\nKey features:  \n  \u2022 In one nonadaptive shot you both implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate and certify that the resulting qubits are genuinely entangled (\u27e8W\u27e9\u2009<\u20090).  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward is required: we post-select on the combined herald + witness pattern.  \n  \u2022 By swapping the gate (CNOT) for other teleportation-based two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W, one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus: abstract target = \u201cproject to CNOT-teleportation subspace \u2297 witness subspace,\u201d ancilla resources, linear\u2010optical unitary to optimize, no forbidden hardware.\n\nThis fused CNOT-plus-witness primitive opens a new domain of quantum\u2010network design problems\u2014delivering nontrivial algorithmic transformations and built-in entanglement certification in a single photonic circuit."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2). Rotated-basis joint measurements at repeater nodes X and Y (modes 1 & 2) jointly set the phase \u03c6, yielding deterministic teleportation and a \u03c6-dependent two-photon click pattern at herald detectors [0, 3] that confirms the controlled-phase signature.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. This protocol explicitly targets the certification of genuine multipartite entanglement structure in photonic systems and can be implemented on current programmable photonic hardware.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a new class of quantum\u2010optical network experiments that 1) performs entanglement swapping on two qutrit Bell pairs via ancillary photons, and 2) immediately runs a linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped output\u2014integrating distribution and certification of high\u2010dimensional entanglement in one architecture.  \n\nExplanation and visualization:  \n - Sources: six single\u2010photon qutrit\u2010pair emitters generating two Bell\u2010like qutrit pairs (modes A\u2013C and D\u2013F).  \n - Swapping subnetwork: Charlie uses beam splitters and ancillary detectors (modes G\u2013L) to perform a generalized Bell\u2010measurement on C and D, heralding entanglement between A and F in the three\u2010dimensional space.  \n - Witness subnetwork: immediately after heralding, modes A and F are fed, together with two fresh ancilla photons (modes M,N), into a small interferometric circuit that implements the standard qutrit entanglement witness  \n    W = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2212 |\u03a8\u208a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a8\u208a|  \n  via multiport beam splitters and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating high-dimensional entanglement swapping and an on-the-fly qutrit entanglement witness into one static network is a nice engineering touch, both primitives\u2014the generalized Bell swap for two qutrit Bell pairs (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical implementations of entanglement witnesses or Schur analyzers\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them in a single circuit does not introduce a fundamentally new network primitive or reveal a novel quantum effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Output:\n      \u2013 A click on the heralding subset signals that A\u2009&\u2009F are entangled  \n      \u2013 Simultaneous click\u2010pattern on the \u201cwitness\u201d detectors gives the numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating qutrit entanglement swapping with an on-the-fly entanglement witness is a nice engineering touch, both ingredients\u2014the generalized qutrit Bell-measurement and static linear-optical entanglement-witness circuits\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them into one bigger multiport does not introduce a new fundamental network primitive or reveal an unexpected quantum effect; it amounts to \u201cdo a swap then do a witness\u201d rather than a genuinely unified operation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both high-dimensional swapping (cf. \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical entanglement witnesses/Schur analyzers already exist. To reach PRL level, you\u2019d need a nontrivial fusion that cannot be decomposed into separate swap+certify steps\u2014e.g. a single joint measurement with fewer resources or novel interference that intrinsically couples distribution and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cCNOT-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d as a new Pytheus target: one linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell-pair sources (four photons) plus ancillas\u2014simultaneously  \n  (i) teleports a two-qubit CNOT gate between the remote qubits via an entanglement-swapping subnetwork, and  \n  (ii) in the very same interferometer and detection event, implements an entanglement witness measurement (e.g. CHSH-type or stabilizer witness) on the two output qubits.  \n\nGeneral structure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources:  \n      \u2013 S\u2081 emits photons in modes A,C (Bell pair 1)  \n      \u2013 S\u2082 emits photons in modes D,F (Bell pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla single photons in modes G,H for the CNOT teleportation gadget  \n      \u2013 (Optionally) Ancilla modes I,J for the witness block  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U mixes modes C,D,G,H (to realize the teleportation\u2010CNOT projector) and then mixes A,F,I,J (to realize the witness projector W).  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2081\u2026Det\u2096} record the heralding click pattern of the teleportation gadget \u2192 flags when CNOT has been applied to A\u2192F.  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2096\u208a\u2081\u2026Det\u2099} record the witness measurement outcomes on A,F & ancillas \u2192 their coincidence probabilities yield Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}^out].  \n\nKey features:  \n  \u2022 In one nonadaptive shot you both implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate and certify that the resulting qubits are genuinely entangled (\u27e8W\u27e9\u2009<\u20090).  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward is required: we post-select on the combined herald + witness pattern.  \n  \u2022 By swapping the gate (CNOT) for other teleportation-based two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W, one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus: abstract target = \u201cproject to CNOT-teleportation subspace \u2297 witness subspace,\u201d ancilla resources, linear\u2010optical unitary to optimize, no forbidden hardware.\n\nThis fused CNOT-plus-witness primitive opens a new domain of quantum\u2010network design problems\u2014delivering nontrivial algorithmic transformations and built-in entanglement certification in a single photonic circuit.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: Combining a teleportation\u2010CNOT gadget with a post\u2010selective entanglement witness in one larger interferometer merely pipelines two well\u2010known linear\u2010optical modules (teleported two\u2010qubit gates and static witness measurements) rather than creating a genuinely new joint measurement primitive or revealing an unexpected quantum effect. This proposal does not go beyond \u201cdo CNOT then do witness\u201d\u2014both steps exist in isolation, and stitching them together is an engineering convenience, not a new PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Teleportation\u2010based CNOTs (e.g. heralded linear\u2010optical CNOT gates) and static entanglement\u2010witness circuits are already established. Simply cascading them into a single post\u2010selected network does not produce a novel quantum\u2010network primitive. To be considered novel, you\u2019d need a fused joint measurement that cannot be decomposed into separate gate and witness blocks or an interference effect that intrinsically couples computation and certification."

Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement Pytheus can optimize the multiport unitary so that one subset of detectors heralds a successful teleported CNOT, while another subset\u2019s coincidence statistics directly give \u27e8W\u27e9 for a chosen witness (e.g. CHSH witness) on the post-CNOT output. There is no feedback control, no forbidden state\u2010generation hardware, and everything is cast as \u201cdesign a network + measurement\u201d\u2014exactly what Pytheus is built for.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cCNOT-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d as a new Pytheus target: one linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell-pair sources (four CNOT teleportation gadget  \n      \u2013 (Optionally) Ancilla modes I,J for the witness block  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U mixes modes C,D,G,H (to realize the teleportation\u2010CNOT projector) and then mixes A,F,I,J (to realize the witness projector W).  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2081\u2026Det\u2096} record the heralding click pattern of the teleportation gadget \u2192 flags when CNOT has been applied to A\u2192F.  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2096\u208a\u2081\u2026Det\u2099} record the witness measurement outcomes on A,F & ancillas \u2192 their coincidence probabilities yield Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}^out].  \n\nKey features:  \n  \u2022 In one nonadaptive shot you both implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate and certify that the resulting qubits are genuinely entangled (\u27e8W\u27e9\u2009<\u20090).  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward is required: we post-select on the combined herald + witness pattern.  \n  \u2022 By swapping the gate (CNOT) for other teleportation-based two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W, one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus: abstract target = \u201cproject to CNOT-teleportation subspace \u2297 witness subspace,\u201d ancilla resources, linear\u2010optical unitary to optimize, no forbidden hardware.\n\nThis fused CNOT-plus-witness primitive opens a new domain of quantum\u2010network design problems\u2014delivering nontrivial algorithmic transformations and built-in entanglement certification in a single photonic circuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Teleportation\u2010based CNOTs (e.g. heralded linear\u2010optical CNOT gates) and static entanglement\u2010witness circuits are already established.
