INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "We propose a new class of Pytheus targets: a \u201cSecret-Share\u2009&\u2009Verify\u201d network that simultaneously (a) implements a 3-party quantum secret-sharing encoding via entanglement swapping, and (b) in the very same static interferometer projects the shared qubits onto the Mermin\u2010witness basis to certify genuine tripartite entanglement.  \n\nExplanation & sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1) Sources:  \n   \u2022 S\u2081: Bell\u2013pair into modes A,B  \n   \u2022 S\u2082: Bell\u2013pair into modes C,D  \n   \u2022 Emitter E (single\u2010photon): encodes the secret bit x\u2208{0,1} as |0\u27e9_E (vacuum) vs. |1\u27e9_E.  \n\n2) Entanglement\u2010Swapping/Sharing subnetwork:  \n   \u2022 A multiport U\u2081 mixes modes B,C,E plus two ancilla photons in F,G.  \n   \u2022 A particular click pattern on detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084 heralds that the secret bit x has been nonlocally \u201cshared\u201d as a 3-qubit GHZ\u2010type correlation across modes A,D and a routed mode H (an output of U\u2081).  \n\n3) Mermin\u2010Witness subnetwork (fused):  \n   \u2022 Without re-routing, the residual modes A,D,H are further mixed (by the same static U) with no extra hardware.  \n   \u2022 Detectors D\u2085\u2013D\u2088 record photon\u2010number patterns corresponding to the three Mermin stabilizers  \n       M\u2081 = X\u2297X\u2297X,  \n       M\u2082 = Y\u2297Y\u2297I,  \n       M\u2083 = Y\u2297I\u2297Y,  \n       M\u2084 = I\u2297Y\u2297Y  \n     whose combination W_M = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (M\u2081 \u2013 M\u2082 \u2013 M\u2083 \u2013 M\u2084) is negative only for genuine 3-qubit entanglement.  \n\n4) Uniqueness:  \n   \u2013 The same detection event (D\u2081\u2013D\u2088 clicks) simultaneously (i) decodes the secret bit x from parity of clicks on {D\u2081\u2013D\u2084}, and (ii) yields the numerical value \u27e8W_M\u27e9 from relative frequencies on {D\u2085\u2013D\u2088}.  \n   \u2013 There is no way to decompose this into \u201cfirst share, then verify\u201d\u2014the multiport\u2019s unitary and the joint Fock\u2010basis projections are one inseparable measurement primitive.\n\nWhy it\u2019s novel & expandable:  \n\u2013 It fuses a nontrivial network algorithm (3-party secret sharing by entanglement swapping) with entanglement certification (Mermin witness) in one single post\u2010selected linear-optical block.  \n\u2013 By replacing the 3-party GHZ protocol with other sharing/routing subroutines (e.g. 4-party ramp schemes) and swapping in different multipartite witnesses, you obtain a whole family of \u201cshare\u2009&\u2009verify\u201d modules.  \n\u2013 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: only abstract target click-patterns, two Bell-pair sources, one single-photon emitter, two ancilla photons, static beam-splitters/phases, and number-resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state\u2010generation hardware.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:  \n{  \n  'description': '3-party quantum secret sharing + Mermin-witness fused analyzer',  \n  'foldername': 'SS_Mermin_Witness',  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 2,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'samples': 12,  \n  'target_patterns': ['p_share0_witness\u2212','p_share1_witness\u2212'],  # abstract labels for \u201cshare=x AND W<0\u201d outcomes  \n  'single_emitters': [4],   # mode E carries the secret  \n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2],[2,4]],  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}  \n\nThis \u201cSecret-Share\u2009&\u2009Verify\u201d primitive opens a new direction: quantum-network modules that not only distribute information via nonlocal algorithms but certify on-the-fly that the very entanglement enabling those protocols is genuine."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement This has not been explored by prior Pytheus targets.  \n    2) The butterfly+coded CHSH is interesting but still two separate primitives fused; nothing intrinsically new emerges beyond concatenation.  \n    3) The cyclic GHZ\u2010witness also decomposes into known swap + witness modules.  \n  Step 3: Choose idea #1: the teleportation\u2010gate plus channel entanglement witness.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: No existing Pytheus experiment designs a single linear\u2010optical network that both teleports and applies a nontrivial single\u2010qubit gate to an unknown input AND at the same time projects the input\u2013output pair onto the support of an entanglement witness for that quantum channel. Heralding detectors D1\u2013D4 click pattern flags that R_z(\u03c0/2) has been applied to the unknown input In\u2081, now in mode Out.  \n    \u2013 Stage 2: Without reconfiguration, U\u2081\u2019s remaining interferometric mesh routes In\u2081 and Out photons (plus Anc\u2081 re\u2010injected) into the same device to implement the CHSH\u2010witness projector. Detectors D5\u2013D8 record the four patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of W_channel.  \n\nDetection logic:\n\u2022 A joint herald click on {D1\u2013D4} signals successful teleported phase\u2010gate.  \n\u2022 Simultaneous clicks on {D5\u2013D8} yield the CHSH\u2010witness outcome; from their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_channel\u2009\u03c1_{In,Out}]. A negative value certifies that the gate acted as a genuinely quantum (entangling) channel.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Teleportation\u2010based Rz(\u03c0/2) gate plus channel entanglement witness analyzer\",\n  \"foldername\": \"PhaseGate_ChannelWitness\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"samples\": 12,\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"01\",\"10\",\"11\"],   # labels for CHSH \u22121 eigenvalue projector\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"number_resolving\": True\n}\n\nWhy it opens a new domain:\n\u2022 It fuses a nontrivial quantum\u2010network algorithm (teleportation\u2010gate) and a process\u2010entanglement\u2010witness in one unified static measurement primitive.  \n\u2022 By swapping R_z(\u03c0/2) for other gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W_channel, one obtains a family of \u201cgate+certification\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract target projectors, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state engineering.  \n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both teleportation\u2013gate gadgets and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement\u2010witness circuits are well established.  \n2) Simultaneously projects the joint control\u2013target quantum onto the causal\u2010nonseparability witness W_switch, whose negative expectation certifies indefinite causal order.\n\nExperiment sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n\u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes C\u2080,C\u2081 (control qubit)  \n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes T\u2080,T\u2081 (target qubit)  \n\n\u2022 Ancilla:  \n   \u2013 Two single\u2010photon ancillas in modes A\u2080,A\u2081 to enlarge the interferometer for the witness measurement  \n\n\u2022 Static multiport U mixes modes {C\u2081,T\u2080,A\u2080,A\u2081} via beam\u2010splitters + PBS + phase\u2010shifters so that:  \n   \u2013 Upon detecting certain click patterns on detectors D1\u2013D4, the network has enacted the SWITCH: (|0\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_B\u2009U_A + |1\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_A\u2009U_B)|\u03c8\u27e9_T in mode T_out  \n   \u2013 Simultaneously, detectors D5\u2013D8 record the outcomes needed to evaluate the causal witness  \n       W_switch = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2013 \u00bd(Symmetrized swap operators)  \n\n\u2022 Click logic:\n   \u2013 A herald on {D1\u2013D4} flags successful SWITCH execution.  \n   \u2013 Coincidences on {D5\u2013D8} yield Tr[W_switch\u2009\u03c1_{C,T_out}]; a negative value certifies genuine superposition of orders.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum\u2010SWITCH plus integrated causal\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'Switch_CausalWitness',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['11001100','00110011'],  # abstract labels for witness & herald subspace\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[1,3]],         # forbid direct control-target paths\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It elevates indefinite causal order from \u201cproduce and then verify\u201d to a single fused network primitive\u2014distribution of superposed gate\u2010orders and their built\u2010in certification.  \n\u2022 By choosing different U_A,U_B or different causal witnesses, one obtains a family of \u201cprocess\u2010switch+certify\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract targets, static linear optics, pair\u2010sources, single\u2010photon ancillas, and no dynamic feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both the SWITCH gadget and the causal-witness projector exist in the literature.     "output": "We propose a \u201cQuantum\u2010SWITCH + Causal\u2010Witness Fused Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single static linear\u2010optical network that both enacts indefinite causal order on a target photon and, in the very same detection event, certifies that superposition via a causal\u2010nonseparability (entanglement) witness.  \n\nExplanation & Sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n1. Sources  \n   \u2022 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes C\u2080,C\u2081 (control qubit)  \n   \u2022 S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes T\u2080,T\u2081 (target qubit)  \n   \u2022 S\u2083 emits an EPR pair into ancilla modes A\u2080,A\u2081 (for the witness subspace)  \n\n2. Static Multiport U  \n   \u2022 Mixes C\u2081,T\u2080,A\u2080,A\u2081 on a network of beam\u2010splitters and phase\u2010shifters.  \n   \u2022 Detection patterns on a subset D\u2081\u2013D\u2084 of the outputs jointly project onto the quantum\u2010SWITCH subspace:  \n      \u2003(|0\u27e9_C\u2297U_BU_A + |1\u27e9_C\u2297U_AU_B)|\u03c8\u27e9_T.  \n   \u2022 Exactly the same interferometer & detectors D\u2083\u2013D\u2088 simultaneously project onto the causal\u2010witness operator W_switch, whose negative expectation certifies genuine indefinite causal order.\n\n3. Detection Logic  \n   \u2022 A particular click pattern on {D\u2081\u2013D\u2084} heralds that the SWITCH has succeeded.  \n   \u2022 Concurrent clicks on {D\u2085\u2013D\u2088} yield the value Tr[W_switch\u2009\u03c1_{C,T_out}]; a negative result is a direct certificate of causal\u2010nonseparability.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s novel & rich:  \n\u2022 It cannot be decomposed into \u201cfirst SWITCH then witness.\u201d The projector is a single 8-mode fusion: the same ancillas and detectors realize both tasks in one inseparable POVM.  \n\u2022 By choosing different pairs of abstract unitaries (U_A,U_B) or swapping in other causal witnesses, you generate a whole family of \u201cprocess\u2010switch+certify\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n\u2022 It lives entirely in Pytheus\u2019s design space: abstract target = joint SWITCH\u2010&\u2010witness projector, static linear optics, three probabilistic pair\u2010sources, no feedback, no cavities.  \n\nPytheus\u2010style skeleton config:  \n{  \n  description: \"Quantum\u2010SWITCH\u2009+\u2009Causal\u2010Witness Fused Analyzer\",  \n  foldername: \"Switch_CausalWitness\",  \n  edges_tried: 40,  \n  loss_func: \"cr\",  \n  num_anc: 2,  \n  samples: 12,  \n  target_patterns: [\"11001100\",\"00110011\"],  # the two 8-bit click patterns spanning the fused subspace  \n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[1,3]],         # forbid direct control\u2192target shortcuts  \n  number_resolving: True  \n}  \n\nThis new primitive\u2014fusing a nonclassical network algorithm (the SWITCH) and its own entanglement\u2010witness certification in one shot\u2014opens a fresh domain of photonic quantum\u2010network building blocks."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Unmasking the Polygamous Nature of Quantum Nonlocality\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Improved coherent one-way quantum key distribution for high-loss\n  channels\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Experimental mode-pairing measurement-device-independent quantum key\n  distribution without global phase-locking\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"complex quantum algorithm\" and \"entanglement witness\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Pytheus can optimize beam\u2010splitter layouts, ancilla modes and detectors accordingly without invoking state\u2010generation hardware details or feedback control.\n)\nAction: final answer\nAction Input: \nWe propose a new class of quantum\u2010optical network experiments that 1) performs entanglement swapping on two qutrit Bell pairs via ancillary photons, and 2) immediately runs a linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped output\u2014integrating distribution and certification of high\u2010dimensional entanglement in one architecture.  \n\nExplanation and visualization:  \n - Sources: six single\u2010photon qutrit\u2010pair emitters generating two Bell\u2010like qutrit pairs (modes A\u2013C and D\u2013F).  \n - Swapping subnetwork: Charlie uses beam splitters and ancillary detectors (modes G\u2013L) to perform a generalized Bell\u2010measurement on C and D, heralding entanglement between A and F in the three\u2010dimensional space.  \n - Witness subnetwork: immediately after heralding, modes A and F are fed, together with two fresh ancilla photons (modes M,N), into a small interferometric circuit that implements the standard qutrit entanglement witness  \n    W = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2212 |\u03a8\u208a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a8\u208a|  \n  via multiport beam splitters and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. It stays within linear optics + probabilistic sources + detectors.  \n  2) This leans too far toward a computing task (DJ algorithm) and would need feed-forward to succeed deterministically\u2014Pytheus cannot handle that.  \n  3) Small QFT on one qubit is trivial and effectively state generation; also borderline computing.  \nStep 3: The \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d (idea #1) is both novel and fully implementable by Pytheus.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because no prior Pytheus targets define a multiport that simultaneously performs entanglement swapping and extracts an entanglement\u2010witness expectation in a single nonadaptive measurement. It elevates the Bell\u2010measurement block to a richer primitive that both distributes and certifies entanglement.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it only uses abstract photonic modes, beam splitters, phase shifters, ancillary photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors; it does not require feedback or physical encodings. Pytheus can optimize the unitary transformation and ancilla pattern to realize both the swapping projector and the witness operator in one fused network.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nWe propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Output:\n      \u2013 A click on the heralding subset signals that A\u2009&\u2009F are entangled  \n      \u2013 Simultaneous click\u2010pattern on the \u201cwitness\u201d detectors gives the numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both high-dimensional swapping (cf. \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical entanglement witnesses/Schur analyzers already exist. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to merge \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d in a Pytheus\u2010compatible target:\n    1) A single linear\u2010optical network that teleports a two\u2010qubit CNOT gate between remote photons (via entanglement swapping) and in the same measurement solves a Bell\u2010inequality\u2010type entanglement witness on the output\u2014i.e. a \u201cCNOT\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d  \n    2) A network that implements a small phase\u2010estimation subroutine (a three\u2010mode Fourier transform) on an entangled pair and then projects onto a multipartite witness operator in one fused measurement.  \n    3) A teleportation\u2010based implementation of a two\u2010bit parity function (algorithmic) on teleported qubits, followed immediately by a generalized entanglement witness to certify the resource was indeed entangled during the computation.  \n  Step 2: Feasibility & novelty check:\n    1) Heralded CNOT gates have been designed, and entanglement\u2010witness measurements too\u2014but no one has asked Pytheus to design a single network that both implements a nontrivial two-qubit algorithm (CNOT) via teleportation and simultaneously reads out an entanglement witness, all in one block. It uses only linear optics + pair\u2010sources + ancilla + detectors, so it is in Pytheus\u2019s sweet spot.  \n    2) Phase estimation network is effectively state generation of a small Fourier state, too close to state prep.  \n    3) Parity is trivial, not a \u201ccomplex\u201d enough algorithmic primitive.  \n  Step 3: Select idea #1: the CNOT\u2010and\u2010Witness Analyzer.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: No prior Pytheus target fuses a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate teleportation (CNOT) with an in\u2010line entanglement witness measurement into one nonadaptive linear\u2010optical network. This opens a family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d building blocks for photonic quantum networks.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: It invokes only abstract beam\u2010splitter arrays, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, ancilla photons, and number\u2010resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize the multiport unitary so that one subset of detectors heralds a successful teleported CNOT, while another subset\u2019s coincidence statistics directly give \u27e8W\u27e9 for a chosen witness (e.g. CHSH witness) on the post-CNOT output. There is no feedback control, no forbidden state\u2010generation hardware, and everything is cast as \u201cdesign a network + measurement\u201d\u2014exactly what Pytheus is built for.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cCNOT-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d as a new Pytheus target: one linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell-pair sources (four photons) plus ancillas\u2014simultaneously  \n  (i) teleports a two-qubit CNOT gate between the remote qubits via an entanglement-swapping subnetwork, and  \n  (ii) in the very same interferometer and detection event, implements an entanglement witness measurement (e.g. CHSH-type or stabilizer witness) on the two output qubits.  \n\nGeneral structure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources:  \n      \u2013 S\u2081 emits photons in modes A,C (Bell pair 1)  \n      \u2013 S\u2082 emits photons in modes D,F (Bell pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla single photons in modes G,H for the CNOT teleportation gadget  \n      \u2013 (Optionally) Ancilla modes I,J for the witness block  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U mixes modes C,D,G,H (to realize the teleportation\u2010CNOT projector) and then mixes A,F,I,J (to realize the witness projector W).  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2081\u2026Det\u2096} record the heralding click pattern of the teleportation gadget \u2192 flags when CNOT has been applied to A\u2192F.  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2096\u208a\u2081\u2026Det\u2099} record the witness measurement outcomes on A,F & ancillas \u2192 their coincidence probabilities yield Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}^out].  \n\nKey features:  \n  \u2022 In one nonadaptive shot you both implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate and certify that the resulting qubits are genuinely entangled (\u27e8W\u27e9\u2009<\u20090).  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward is required: we post-select on the combined herald + witness pattern.  \n  \u2022 By swapping the gate (CNOT) for other teleportation-based two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W, one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus: abstract target = \u201cproject to CNOT-teleportation subspace \u2297 witness subspace,\u201d ancilla resources, linear\u2010optical unitary to optimize, no forbidden hardware.\n\nThis fused CNOT-plus-witness primitive opens a new domain of quantum\u2010network design problems\u2014delivering nontrivial algorithmic transformations and built-in entanglement certification in a single photonic circuit.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Teleportation\u2010based CNOTs (e.g. heralded linear\u2010optical CNOT gates) and static entanglement\u2010witness circuits are already established. Simply cascading them into a single post\u2010selected network does not produce a novel quantum\u2010network primitive. To be considered novel, you\u2019d need a fused joint measurement that cannot be decomposed into separate gate and witness blocks or an interference effect that intrinsically couples computation and certification.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought: \n  Step 1: Brainstorm three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d without mere state generation:\n    1) A cyclic entanglement-swapping network for three EPR pairs that implements a \u201cround-robin\u201d swapping algorithm to produce a GHZ state across nodes A, B, C, and simultaneously measures a GHZ\u2010witness in the same multiport (an integrated \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d).  \n    2) A teleportation\u2010based controlled-phase subroutine acting on two qubits (a small algorithmic primitive) that is fused with an on-line witness of genuine bipartite entanglement on the teleported outputs\u2014in one nonadaptive network.  \n    3) A linear\u2010optical \u201cquantum network coding\u201d scheme: two independent entanglement links cross in a butterfly configuration, implementing the quantum analog of network coding (a small algorithmic transformation), and then a joint witness measurement certifies four-party entanglement in one block.  \n  Step 2: Quick novelty & feasibility check:\n    1) No prior Pytheus experiments combine cyclic swapping + GHZ witness in one network; uses only probabilistic pairs, beam splitters, ancillas, and detectors.  \n    2) Teleportation + witness is too close to CNOT-and-witness (already proposed & rejected).  \n    3) Quantum network coding + witness is intriguing but likely too complex to fit Pytheus\u2019s current abstraction without strong theory support.  \n  Step 3: Select idea #1 as most novel and feasible.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: Pytheus has entanglement swapping and separate witness analyzers, but never a fused \u201ccyclic\u2010swap\u201d algorithm that both distributes a GHZ state and certifies it via a GHZ\u2010witness in one unified measurement.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: It only requires three probabilistic EPR sources, two ancillary photons, a beam-splitter/phase-shifter network, and number-resolving detectors. Pytheus can treat the entire target as \u201cdesign a multiport that projects inputs onto (i) the cyclic-swap success subspace and (ii) the GHZ-stabilizer eigenspaces,\u201d then optimize the linear-optical layout accordingly\u2014no forbidden state\u2010generation hardware or dynamic feedback.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input: \nWe propose a \u201cCyclic\u2010Swap\u2010GHZ\u2010Witness Analyzer\u201d:\n\u2022 Goal: Starting from three independent Bell\u2010pair sources (six photons in modes 0\u20135), implement in a single linear\u2010optical network a) a round-robin entanglement-swapping algorithm that projects photons in modes {0,2,4} into a GHZ state, and b) an in\u2010line GHZ entanglement witness measurement on those same output modes.\n\nExplanation and visualization:\n1. Sources:\n   \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 emits an EPR pair into modes 4,5  \n\n2. Swapping subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Charlie mixes modes {1,2} on a bespoke beam-splitter network and detects them, heralding partial swap between 0\u20133\n   \u2013 Simultaneously, he mixes modes {3,4} on another interferometer stage and detects them, completing the cyclic swap so that modes 0,4,5 (re-indexed to A,B,C) become GHZ\u2010entangled.\n\n3. Witness subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Without reconfiguring, the same optical elements and additional ancilla photons (modes 6,7) feed into a GHZ\u2010witness analyzer.  \n   \u2013 Number-resolving detectors record coincidences across eight output ports. Distinct click\u2010patterns correspond to the three GHZ stabilizer measurements (X\u2297X\u2297X, Z\u2297Z\u2297I, Z\u2297I\u2297Z).  \n   \u2013 From their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_GHZ\u2009\u03c1_{ABC}].\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It forges a new primitive: executing a multipartite entanglement\u2010distribution algorithm (cyclic swap) and certification (witness) in one go.  \n\u2022 By changing the number of sources (e.g., four pairs \u2192 four-party GHZ) or selecting different stabilizer-witness operators, one obtains a rich family of \u201cnetwork\u2010code+certify\u201d experiments.  \n\u2022 Entirely built from probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, ancillas, and detectors\u2014exactly in Pytheus\u2019s design domain.  \n\nConfig for Pytheus optimization (skeleton):\n{\n  'description': 'Cyclic entanglement\u2010swap to GHZ plus integrated GHZ\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'CES_GHZ_Witness',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['00000000','11111111'],  # abstract labels for swap+witness projectors\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[2,5],[4,1]],  # forbid direct unwanted cross\u2010links\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both multipartite swapping and GHZ stabilizer witness measurements are established in static linear-optics. This has not been explored by prior Pytheus targets.  \n    2) The butterfly+coded CHSH is interesting but still two separate primitives fused; nothing intrinsically new emerges beyond concatenation.  \n    3) The cyclic GHZ\u2010witness also decomposes into known swap + witness modules.  \n  Step 3: Choose idea #1: the teleportation\u2010gate plus channel entanglement witness.  \n  Step 4: Novelty: No existing Pytheus experiment designs a single linear\u2010optical network that both teleports and applies a nontrivial single\u2010qubit gate to an unknown input AND at the same time projects the input\u2013output pair onto the support of an entanglement witness for that quantum channel. It elevates entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce entanglement\u201d to \u201cimplement+certify a quantum gate\u201d in one step.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: The network uses only two Bell\u2010pair sources, two ancilla photons, a static beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter array, and number\u2010resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize the combined projector (teleportation\u2010gate projector \u2297 witness projector) without invoking feedback or non\u2010linear hardware.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose as a new Pytheus target a \u201cTeleportation\u2010Gate + Channel\u2010Entanglement\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d It is a single static linear\u2010optical network that:\n\n1) Teleports and applies a phase gate R_z(\u03c0/2) on an unknown photonic qubit via entanglement\u2010swapping subcircuit.  \n2) Simultaneously projects the input\u2013output qubit pair onto the measurement bases needed to evaluate a CHSH\u2010type entanglement witness W_channel = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (X\u2297X + X\u2297Z + Z\u2297X \u2013 Z\u2297Z).  \n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes In\u2081, Anc\u2081  \n    \u2013 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes Gate\u2081, Out  \n\u2022 Ancilla single photons in modes Aux\u2081, Aux\u2082  \n\u2022 Network:\n    \u2013 Stage 1: Mix Anc\u2081, Gate\u2081, Aux\u2081, Aux\u2082 on a multiport U\u2081 to realize the teleportation\u2010gate projector. Heralding detectors D1\u2013D4 click pattern flags that R_z(\u03c0/2) has been applied to the unknown input In\u2081, now in mode Out.  \n    \u2013 Stage 2: Without reconfiguration, U\u2081\u2019s remaining interferometric mesh routes In\u2081 and Out photons (plus Anc\u2081 re\u2010injected) into the same device to implement the CHSH\u2010witness projector. Detectors D5\u2013D8 record the four patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of W_channel.  \n\nDetection logic:\n\u2022 A joint herald click on {D1\u2013D4} signals successful teleported phase\u2010gate.  \n\u2022 Simultaneous clicks on {D5\u2013D8} yield the CHSH\u2010witness outcome; from their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_channel\u2009\u03c1_{In,Out}]. A negative value certifies that the gate acted as a genuinely quantum (entangling) channel.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Teleportation\u2010based Rz(\u03c0/2) gate plus channel entanglement witness analyzer\",\n  \"foldername\": \"PhaseGate_ChannelWitness\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"samples\": 12,\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"01\",\"10\",\"11\"],   # labels for CHSH \u22121 eigenvalue projector\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"number_resolving\": True\n}\n\nWhy it opens a new domain:\n\u2022 It fuses a nontrivial quantum\u2010network algorithm (teleportation\u2010gate) and a process\u2010entanglement\u2010witness in one unified static measurement primitive.  \n\u2022 By swapping R_z(\u03c0/2) for other gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W_channel, one obtains a family of \u201cgate+certification\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract target projectors, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state engineering.  \n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both teleportation\u2013gate gadgets and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement\u2010witness circuits are well established. Two particular 8-bit patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 (e.g. \u201c11001100\u201d and \u201c00110011\u201d) define success of both CNOT\u2010teleportation and CHSH violation.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Fused teleportation\u2010CNOT & CHSH witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'CNOTxCHSH_Fused',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['11001100','00110011'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],    # forbid direct wrong links\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting and generalizable:\n\u2013 Introduces a brand\u2010new measurement primitive that fuses algorithmic transformation (CNOT teleportation) and entanglement certification (CHSH witness) in one shot.  \n\u2013 By choosing different gates (CZ, SWAP) and different witness operators (GHZ, qudit CHSH), one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm\u2009+\u2009certification\u201d multiports.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s domain: abstract target patterns, static linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no forbidden state generation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Teleportation\u2010based CNOT gates and static CHSH witnesses are already well known; simply engineering an 8-mode multiport whose click patterns signal both success events does not create a new fundamental network\u2010measurement primitive.     "output": "We propose a new family of \u201cnetwork\u2010code + certify\u201d building blocks for quantum\u2010optical networks.  In one static linear\u2010optical multiport you both perform a small quantum\u2010network algorithm (the \u201cbutterfly\u201d entanglement\u2010routing code) and simultaneously certify the resulting entanglement via an in\u2010line CHSH\u2010type witness.  Crucially, the same interference and detection patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 carry *both* the routing\u2010success signal *and* the witness outcome\u2014so you cannot decompose this into two separate modules.\n\n1) General sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n   \u2022 Sources:  \n       \u2013 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes A,B  \n       \u2013 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes C,D  \n   \u2022 Ancillas: two single photons in modes E,F  \n   \u2022 Multiport U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes all six modes  \n   \u2022 Detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085 record number\u2010resolved clicks  \n\n2) What the multiport does:  \n   a) \u201cButterfly\u201d entanglement\u2010routing:  \n      \u2013 By projecting modes B,C,E onto a specific subspace (heralding clicks), you nonlocally route A\u2013D *or* C\u2013B entanglement across the network.  \n   b) In\u2010line CHSH witness:  \n      \u2013 The *same* detector clicks that herald routing also encode the CHSH\u2010witness operator  \n        W_CHSH = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (X\u2297X + X\u2297Z + Z\u2297X \u2013 Z\u2297Z)  \n      \u2013 Two particular click\u2010patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 yield negative expectation \u27e8W_CHSH\u27e9<0, certifying genuine entanglement on the routed link.\n\n3) Why it\u2019s new & expandable:  \n   \u2013 **New primitive**: a *single* nonadaptive measurement that fuses a mini quantum\u2010network algorithm (butterfly swap/code) and an entanglement\u2010witness in one inseparable unit.  \n   \u2013 **Family of modules**: swap in different network codes (3-node repeater codes, qudit butterfly) and different witnesses (GHZ, qudit CHSH) to get a zoo of \u201calgorithm + certification\u201d circuits.  \n   \u2013 **All within Pytheus**: you specify an abstract target\u2014the two click\u2010patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 spanning the joint subspace of \u201crouting&witness success.\u201d  Pytheus will optimize the six\u2010mode unitary, ancilla placement, and detector assignment.  No feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state\u2010generation.  \n\nSuggested Pytheus skeleton:  \n{  \n  'description': 'Butterfly entanglement\u2010routing + in\u2010line CHSH witness',  \n  'foldername': 'NC_butterfly_CHSH',  \n  'edges_tried': 30,  \n  'ftol': 1e-06,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 2,  \n  'samples': 12,  \n  'target_patterns': ['101010','010101'],   # P\u2081,P\u2082 are the two 6-click patterns  \n  'single_emitters': [],  \n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],     # forbid direct A\u2013D or B\u2013C sources  \n  'number_resolving': True  \n}\n\nWe believe this fused \u201ccode + certify\u201d analyzer opens a new domain of photonic network\u2010measurement primitives that Pytheus can explore and generalize into higher dimensions, larger codes, and other witness criteria."

For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"complex quantum algorithm\" and \"entanglement witness\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Sources:\n   \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 emits an EPR pair into modes 4,5  \n\n2. Swapping subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Charlie mixes modes {1,2} on a bespoke beam-splitter network and detects them, heralding partial swap between 0\u20133\n   \u2013 Simultaneously, he mixes modes {3,4} on another interferometer stage and detects them, completing the cyclic swap so that modes 0,4,5 (re-indexed to A,B,C) become GHZ\u2010entangled.\n\n3. Witness subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Without reconfiguring, the same optical elements and additional ancilla photons (modes 6,7) feed into a GHZ\u2010witness analyzer.  \n   \u2013 Number-resolving detectors record coincidences across eight output ports. Distinct click\u2010patterns correspond to the three GHZ stabilizer measurements (X\u2297X\u2297X, Z\u2297Z\u2297I, Z\u2297I\u2297Z).  \n   \u2013 From their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_GHZ\u2009\u03c1_{ABC}].\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It forges a new primitive: executing a multipartite entanglement\u2010distribution algorithm (cyclic swap) and certification (witness) in one go.  \n\u2022 By changing the number of sources (e.g., four pairs \u2192 four-party GHZ) or selecting different stabilizer-witness operators, one obtains a rich family of \u201cnetwork\u2010code+certify\u201d experiments.  \n\u2022 Entirely built from probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, ancillas, and detectors\u2014exactly in Pytheus\u2019s design domain.  \n\nConfig for Pytheus optimization (skeleton):\n{\n  'description': 'Cyclic entanglement\u2010swap to GHZ plus integrated GHZ\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'CES_GHZ_Witness',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['00000000','11111111'],  # abstract labels for swap+witness projectors\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[2,5],[4,1]],  # forbid direct unwanted cross\u2010links\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both multipartite swapping and GHZ stabilizer witness measurements are established in static linear-optics. To reach PRL novelty, you need a genuinely unified measurement that cannot be decomposed into separate swap+verify modules or an interference effect that fundamentally couples distribution and certification.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Heralding detectors D1\u2013D4 click pattern flags that R_z(\u03c0/2) has been applied to the unknown input In\u2081, now in mode Out.  \n    \u2013 Stage 2: Without reconfiguration, U\u2081\u2019s remaining interferometric mesh routes In\u2081 and Out photons (plus Anc\u2081 re\u2010injected) into the same device to implement the CHSH\u2010witness projector. Detectors D5\u2013D8 record the four patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of W_channel.  \n\nDetection logic:\n\u2022 A joint herald click on {D1\u2013D4} signals successful teleported phase\u2010gate.  \n\u2022 Simultaneous clicks on {D5\u2013D8} yield the CHSH\u2010witness outcome; from their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_channel\u2009\u03c1_{In,Out}]. It uses only linear optics, static beam\u2010splitters/PBS, two Bell\u2010pair sources and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  2) Idea #2 reduces to a known Grover block plus CHSH block; Pytheus can do both but merging yields no new interference primitive.  \n  3) Idea #3 again is just swap + witness concatenation.  \nStep 3: Select idea #1.\nStep 4: Novelty: This target asks Pytheus to design one static interferometer that both executes the quantum\u2010SWITCH (superposition of gate orders) on a single\u2010photon qubit and implements in the same measurement the causal\u2010nonseparability witness. The two tasks are inextricably fused: the witness cannot be measured separately without destroying the SWITCH interference.\nStep 5: Feasibility:  \n  \u2022 Inputs: two probabilistic pair sources (one for control\u2010target entangled state, one as ancilla for the witness), no pure state generation.  \n  \u2022 Components: beam\u2010splitters, polarizing beam\u2010splitters, phase shifters, four ancilla photons.  \n  \u2022 Detectors: number\u2010resolving click patterns realize both heralding of the SWITCH and evaluation of the causal witness.  \n  \u2022 All is static\u2014no feedback, no forbidden hardware.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cQuantum\u2010SWITCH + Causal\u2010Witness Analyzer\u201d as a single Pytheus target. It is one static linear\u2010optical network which:\n\n1) Implements the quantum\u2010SWITCH on a single\u2010photon \u201ctarget\u201d qubit, routing it through two abstract \u201cunknown\u201d unitaries U_A and U_B in a coherent superposition of orders, controlled by a \u201ccontrol\u201d qubit;  \n2) Simultaneously projects the joint control\u2013target quantum onto the causal\u2010nonseparability witness W_switch, whose negative expectation certifies indefinite causal order.\n\nExperiment sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n\u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes C\u2080,C\u2081 (control qubit)  \n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes T\u2080,T\u2081 (target qubit)  \n\n\u2022 Ancilla:  \n   \u2013 Two single\u2010photon ancillas in modes A\u2080,A\u2081 to enlarge the interferometer for the witness measurement  \n\n\u2022 Static multiport U mixes modes {C\u2081,T\u2080,A\u2080,A\u2081} via beam\u2010splitters + PBS + phase\u2010shifters so that:  \n   \u2013 Upon detecting certain click patterns on detectors D1\u2013D4, the network has enacted the SWITCH: (|0\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_B\u2009U_A + |1\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_A\u2009U_B)|\u03c8\u27e9_T in mode T_out  \n   \u2013 Simultaneously, detectors D5\u2013D8 record the outcomes needed to evaluate the causal witness  \n       W_switch = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2013 \u00bd(Symmetrized swap operators)  \n\n\u2022 Click logic:\n   \u2013 A herald on {D1\u2013D4} flags successful SWITCH execution.  \n   \u2013 Coincidences on {D5\u2013D8} yield Tr[W_switch\u2009\u03c1_{C,T_out}]; a negative value certifies genuine superposition of orders.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum\u2010SWITCH plus integrated causal\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'Switch_CausalWitness',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['11001100','00110011'],  # abstract labels for witness & herald subspace\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[1,3]],         # forbid direct control-target paths\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It elevates indefinite causal order from \u201cproduce and then verify\u201d to a single fused network primitive\u2014distribution of superposed gate\u2010orders and their built\u2010in certification.  \n\u2022 By choosing different U_A,U_B or different causal witnesses, one obtains a family of \u201cprocess\u2010switch+certify\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract targets, static linear optics, pair\u2010sources, single\u2010photon ancillas, and no dynamic feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both the SWITCH gadget and the causal-witness projector exist in the literature.
