    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a new class of quantum\u2010optical network experiments that 1) performs entanglement swapping on two qutrit Bell pairs via ancillary photons, and 2) immediately runs a linear\u2010optical entanglement\u2010witness measurement on the swapped output\u2014integrating distribution and certification of high\u2010dimensional entanglement in one architecture.  \n\nExplanation and visualization:  \n - Sources: six single\u2010photon qutrit\u2010pair emitters generating two Bell\u2010like qutrit pairs (modes A\u2013C and D\u2013F).  \n - Swapping subnetwork: Charlie uses beam splitters and ancillary detectors (modes G\u2013L) to perform a generalized Bell\u2010measurement on C and D, heralding entanglement between A and F in the three\u2010dimensional space.  \n - Witness subnetwork: immediately after heralding, modes A and F are fed, together with two fresh ancilla photons (modes M,N), into a small interferometric circuit that implements the standard qutrit entanglement witness  \n    W = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2212 |\u03a8\u208a\u27e9\u27e8\u03a8\u208a|  \n  via multiport beam splitters and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors. Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating high-dimensional entanglement swapping and an on-the-fly qutrit entanglement witness into one static network is a nice engineering touch, both primitives\u2014the generalized Bell swap for two qutrit Bell pairs (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical implementations of entanglement witnesses or Schur analyzers\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them in a single circuit does not introduce a fundamentally new network primitive or reveal a novel quantum effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. Merging them into one architecture is an incremental integration rather than a new quantum\u2010network target. To be PRL-worthy you\u2019d need a truly new measurement primitive or an unexpected nontrivial interplay between distribution and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cSwap-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d\u2014a single linear-optical network that takes two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (four input photons) plus ancillary photons, and by a suitably optimized multiport performs:\n  1. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern directly yields Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].\n\nVisualization:\n  \u2022 Input modes:\n      \u2013 Sources S\u2081 emit photons in modes A\u2013C (entangled pair 1)  \n      \u2013 Sources S\u2082 emit photons in modes D\u2013F (entangled pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla photons in modes G, H  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U (beam splitters + phase shifters) mixes C,D,G,H,A,F  \n  \u2022 Detectors:\n      \u2013 Heralding detectors on some outputs of U \u2192 confirms successful swap  \n      \u2013 Witness detectors on the remaining outputs \u2192 specific coincidences compute \u27e8W\u27e9  \n  \u2022 Output:\n      \u2013 A click on the heralding subset signals that A\u2009&\u2009F are entangled  \n      \u2013 Simultaneous click\u2010pattern on the \u201cwitness\u201d detectors gives the numerical value of the witness, certifying genuine high\u2010D entanglement in \u03c1_{AF}.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 It lifts entanglement swapping from \u201cproduce state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different W, one obtains a family of Swap-and-Witness Analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Such fused measurement blocks could become modular subroutines in larger quantum\u2010network protocols\u2014delivering entanglement and proof in a single operation.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s scope: abstract target description (swap + witness projector), no feedback, no cavities\u2014pure linear optics + ancilla + detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While integrating qutrit entanglement swapping with an on-the-fly entanglement witness is a nice engineering touch, both ingredients\u2014the generalized qutrit Bell-measurement and static linear-optical entanglement-witness circuits\u2014are already well explored. Simply cascading them into one bigger multiport does not introduce a new fundamental network primitive or reveal an unexpected quantum effect; it amounts to \u201cdo a swap then do a witness\u201d rather than a genuinely unified operation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both high-dimensional swapping (cf. \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) and linear-optical entanglement witnesses/Schur analyzers already exist. To reach PRL level, you\u2019d need a nontrivial fusion that cannot be decomposed into separate swap+certify steps\u2014e.g. a single joint measurement with fewer resources or novel interference that intrinsically couples distribution and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cCNOT-and-Witness Analyzer\u201d as a new Pytheus target: one linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell-pair sources (four photons) plus ancillas\u2014simultaneously  \n  (i) teleports a two-qubit CNOT gate between the remote qubits via an entanglement-swapping subnetwork, and  \n  (ii) in the very same interferometer and detection event, implements an entanglement witness measurement (e.g. CHSH-type or stabilizer witness) on the two output qubits.  \n\nGeneral structure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):  \n  \u2022 Sources:  \n      \u2013 S\u2081 emits photons in modes A,C (Bell pair 1)  \n      \u2013 S\u2082 emits photons in modes D,F (Bell pair 2)  \n      \u2013 Ancilla single photons in modes G,H for the CNOT teleportation gadget  \n      \u2013 (Optionally) Ancilla modes I,J for the witness block  \n  \u2022 Multiport network U mixes modes C,D,G,H (to realize the teleportation\u2010CNOT projector) and then mixes A,F,I,J (to realize the witness projector W).  \n  \u2022 Detectors:  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2081\u2026Det\u2096} record the heralding click pattern of the teleportation gadget \u2192 flags when CNOT has been applied to A\u2192F.  \n      \u2013 {Det\u2096\u208a\u2081\u2026Det\u2099} record the witness measurement outcomes on A,F & ancillas \u2192 their coincidence probabilities yield Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}^out].  \n\nKey features:  \n  \u2022 In one nonadaptive shot you both implement a nontrivial two\u2010qubit gate and certify that the resulting qubits are genuinely entangled (\u27e8W\u27e9\u2009<\u20090).  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feed-forward is required: we post-select on the combined herald + witness pattern.  \n  \u2022 By swapping the gate (CNOT) for other teleportation-based two-qubit gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W, one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d modules for quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Entirely within Pytheus: abstract target = \u201cproject to CNOT-teleportation subspace \u2297 witness subspace,\u201d ancilla resources, linear\u2010optical unitary to optimize, no forbidden hardware.\n\nThis fused CNOT-plus-witness primitive opens a new domain of quantum\u2010network design problems\u2014delivering nontrivial algorithmic transformations and built-in entanglement certification in a single photonic circuit.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: Combining a teleportation\u2010CNOT gadget with a post\u2010selective entanglement witness in one larger interferometer merely pipelines two well\u2010known linear\u2010optical modules (teleported two\u2010qubit gates and static witness measurements) rather than creating a genuinely new joint measurement primitive or revealing an unexpected quantum effect. This proposal does not go beyond \u201cdo CNOT then do witness\u201d\u2014both steps exist in isolation, and stitching them together is an engineering convenience, not a new PRL\u2010level target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Teleportation\u2010based CNOTs (e.g. heralded linear\u2010optical CNOT gates) and static entanglement\u2010witness circuits are already established. Simply cascading them into a single post\u2010selected network does not produce a novel quantum\u2010network primitive. To be considered novel, you\u2019d need a fused joint measurement that cannot be decomposed into separate gate and witness blocks or an interference effect that intrinsically couples computation and certification.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cCyclic\u2010Swap\u2010GHZ\u2010Witness Analyzer\u201d:\n\u2022 Goal: Starting from three independent Bell\u2010pair sources (six photons in modes 0\u20135), implement in a single linear\u2010optical network a) a round-robin entanglement-swapping algorithm that projects photons in modes {0,2,4} into a GHZ state, and b) an in\u2010line GHZ entanglement witness measurement on those same output modes.\n\nExplanation and visualization:\n1. Sources:\n   \u2013 S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes 0,1  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes 2,3  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 emits an EPR pair into modes 4,5  \n\n2. Swapping subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Charlie mixes modes {1,2} on a bespoke beam-splitter network and detects them, heralding partial swap between 0\u20133\n   \u2013 Simultaneously, he mixes modes {3,4} on another interferometer stage and detects them, completing the cyclic swap so that modes 0,4,5 (re-indexed to A,B,C) become GHZ\u2010entangled.\n\n3. Witness subnetwork:\n   \u2013 Without reconfiguring, the same optical elements and additional ancilla photons (modes 6,7) feed into a GHZ\u2010witness analyzer.  \n   \u2013 Number-resolving detectors record coincidences across eight output ports. Distinct click\u2010patterns correspond to the three GHZ stabilizer measurements (X\u2297X\u2297X, Z\u2297Z\u2297I, Z\u2297I\u2297Z).  \n   \u2013 From their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_GHZ\u2009\u03c1_{ABC}].\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It forges a new primitive: executing a multipartite entanglement\u2010distribution algorithm (cyclic swap) and certification (witness) in one go.  \n\u2022 By changing the number of sources (e.g., four pairs \u2192 four-party GHZ) or selecting different stabilizer-witness operators, one obtains a rich family of \u201cnetwork\u2010code+certify\u201d experiments.  \n\u2022 Entirely built from probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, ancillas, and detectors\u2014exactly in Pytheus\u2019s design domain.  \n\nConfig for Pytheus optimization (skeleton):\n{\n  'description': 'Cyclic entanglement\u2010swap to GHZ plus integrated GHZ\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'CES_GHZ_Witness',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['00000000','11111111'],  # It fuses a butterfly\u2010style entanglement\u2010swapping network\u2010coding subroutine with an in\u2010line CHSH entanglement\u2010witness measurement in one static linear\u2010optical circuit.\n\nExperiment sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n1. Sources:\n   \u2022 Probabilistic Bell\u2010pair S\u2081 \u2192 modes A,B  \n   \u2022 Probabilistic Bell\u2010pair S\u2082 \u2192 modes C,D  \n   \u2022 Ancilla single photons \u2192 modes E,F  \n\n2. Network\u2010Coding Subblock:\n   \u2022 Central multiport U\u2081 mixes modes B,C,E (beam splitters + phases)  \n   \u2022 Detectors D1\u2013D3 record a specific heralding pattern\u2014this implements the quantum \u201cbutterfly\u201d projector, routing entanglement so that A\u2194D and C\u2194B are correlated post\u2010selection.\n\n3. CHSH\u2010Witness Subblock:\n   \u2022 In the same optical layout (no reconfiguration), the surviving photons in modes A,D and ancillas F,G are mixed by U\u2082  \n   \u2022 Detectors D4\u2013D7 record the four relevant coincidence patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of the CHSH witness operator\n       W_CHSH = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (X\u2297X + X\u2297Z + Z\u2297X \u2013 Z\u2297Z).\n   \u2022 From their frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_CHSH\u2009\u03c1_{AD}].\n\nTopology constraint:\n   \u2022 removed_connections = [[A,D],[B,C]] to forbid any direct source linking senders with wrong receivers.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Butterfly quantum network coding + CHSH witness fused analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'QNC_CHSH_Witness',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['0101','1010'],    # bit\u2010strings for CHSH \u22121 outcomes on A/D vs ancillas\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting and expandable:\n \u2022 Defines a new primitive: execute a nontrivial quantum\u2010network algorithm (butterfly entanglement routing) and certify the resulting entanglement in a single nonadaptive measurement.\n \u2022 Swapping in other small network algorithms (3\u2010node coding, qudit \u201cbutterfly\u201d) and other witnesses (GHZ, qudit CHSH) yields a rich family of \u201calgorithm\u2009+\u2009certification\u201d modules.\n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract target (swap + witness projectors), static linear optics, ancilla photons, and detectors\u2014no state generation or feedback.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While fusing a butterfly\u2010style network\u2010coded entanglement swap with an in\u2010line CHSH witness in one static circuit is an interesting integration, both ingredients\u2014the four\u2010photon \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding projector and static CHSH\u2010witness measurements\u2014have already appeared in prior proposals (see the ensemble\u2019s Butterfly Network\u2010Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement and numerous entanglement\u2010witness analyzers). To be novel at the PRL level you\u2019d need a fused measurement that cannot be decomposed into separate coding+witness steps or an intrinsic quantum\u2010network effect emerging only in the combined scheme.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose as a new Pytheus target a \u201cTeleportation\u2010Gate + Channel\u2010Entanglement\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d It is a single static linear\u2010optical network that:\n\n1) Teleports and applies a phase gate R_z(\u03c0/2) on an unknown photonic qubit via entanglement\u2010swapping subcircuit.  \n2) Simultaneously projects the input\u2013output qubit pair onto the measurement bases needed to evaluate a CHSH\u2010type entanglement witness W_channel = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (X\u2297X + X\u2297Z + Z\u2297X \u2013 Z\u2297Z).  \n\nVisualization (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\u2022 Sources:\n    \u2013 S\u2081 emits a Bell pair into modes In\u2081, Anc\u2081  \n    \u2013 S\u2082 emits a Bell pair into modes Gate\u2081, Out  \n\u2022 Ancilla single photons in modes Aux\u2081, Aux\u2082  \n\u2022 Network:\n    \u2013 Stage 1: Mix Anc\u2081, Gate\u2081, Aux\u2081, Aux\u2082 on a multiport U\u2081 to realize the teleportation\u2010gate projector. Heralding detectors D1\u2013D4 click pattern flags that R_z(\u03c0/2) has been applied to the unknown input In\u2081, now in mode Out.  \n    \u2013 Stage 2: Without reconfiguration, U\u2081\u2019s remaining interferometric mesh routes In\u2081 and Out photons (plus Anc\u2081 re\u2010injected) into the same device to implement the CHSH\u2010witness projector. Detectors D5\u2013D8 record the four patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of W_channel.  \n\nDetection logic:\n\u2022 A joint herald click on {D1\u2013D4} signals successful teleported phase\u2010gate.  \n\u2022 Simultaneous clicks on {D5\u2013D8} yield the CHSH\u2010witness outcome; from their relative frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_channel\u2009\u03c1_{In,Out}]. A negative value certifies that the gate acted as a genuinely quantum (entangling) channel.  \n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Teleportation\u2010based Rz(\u03c0/2) gate plus channel entanglement witness analyzer\",\n  \"foldername\": \"PhaseGate_ChannelWitness\",\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"cr\",\n  \"num_anc\": 2,\n  \"samples\": 12,\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"01\",\"10\",\"11\"],   # labels for CHSH \u22121 eigenvalue projector\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  \"number_resolving\": True\n}\n\nWhy it opens a new domain:\n\u2022 It fuses a nontrivial quantum\u2010network algorithm (teleportation\u2010gate) and a process\u2010entanglement\u2010witness in one unified static measurement primitive.  \n\u2022 By swapping R_z(\u03c0/2) for other gates (CZ, SWAP) and changing W_channel, one obtains a family of \u201cgate+certification\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract target projectors, probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state engineering.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While combining a teleportation\u2010gate subroutine with an in\u2010line CHSH witness sounds like a tidy integration, it is essentially the same \u201calgorithm\u2009+\u2009certification\u201d motif that\u2019s already been proposed (e.g. the ensemble\u2019s butterfly network + CHSH\u2010witness analyzer). Teleporting R_z(\u03c0/2) instead of routing entanglement does not create a new joint measurement primitive or reveal an unexpected interference effect\u2014it\u2019s just \u201cdo teleportation\u2010gate then do witness\u201d in one bigger interferometer.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both teleportation\u2013gate gadgets and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement\u2010witness circuits are well established. Each pattern simultaneously signals \u201cCNOT succeeded\u201d and \u201cCHSH\u2010beat threshold.\u201d  \n\u2022 This fused measurement cannot be decomposed into two independent subcircuits; it exploits interference between gate\u2010ancillas and witness\u2010ancillas.\n\nGeneral structure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n1. Two particular 8-bit patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 (e.g. \u201c11001100\u201d and \u201c00110011\u201d) define success of both CNOT\u2010teleportation and CHSH violation.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Fused teleportation\u2010CNOT & CHSH witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'CNOTxCHSH_Fused',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['11001100','00110011'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],    # forbid direct wrong links\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting and generalizable:\n\u2013 Introduces a brand\u2010new measurement primitive that fuses algorithmic transformation (CNOT teleportation) and entanglement certification (CHSH witness) in one shot.  \n\u2013 By choosing different gates (CZ, SWAP) and different witness operators (GHZ, qudit CHSH), one obtains a whole family of \u201calgorithm\u2009+\u2009certification\u201d multiports.  \n\u2013 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s domain: abstract target patterns, static linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no forbidden state generation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: Although the idea of an inseparable joint measurement that both teleports a CNOT and certifies CHSH violation is pitched as a \u201cfused\u201d primitive, it still amounts to stitching together two established linear\u2010optical subroutines (teleportation\u2010CNOT gadgets and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement witnesses) into one larger interferometer. A PRL\u2010worthy proposal would need an inseparable joint projector or an unexpected quantum\u2010network phenomenon that emerges only in the combined scheme, not just an integrated pipeline of two known operations.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cQuantum\u2010SWITCH + Causal\u2010Witness Analyzer\u201d as a single Pytheus target. It is one static linear\u2010optical network which:\n\n1) Implements the quantum\u2010SWITCH on a single\u2010photon \u201ctarget\u201d qubit, routing it through two abstract \u201cunknown\u201d unitaries U_A and U_B in a coherent superposition of orders, controlled by a \u201ccontrol\u201d qubit;  \n2) Simultaneously projects the joint control\u2013target quantum onto the causal\u2010nonseparability witness W_switch, whose negative expectation certifies indefinite causal order.\n\nExperiment sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n\u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes C\u2080,C\u2081 (control qubit)  \n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes T\u2080,T\u2081 (target qubit)  \n\n\u2022 Ancilla:  \n   \u2013 Two single\u2010photon ancillas in modes A\u2080,A\u2081 to enlarge the interferometer for the witness measurement  \n\n\u2022 Static multiport U mixes modes {C\u2081,T\u2080,A\u2080,A\u2081} via beam\u2010splitters + PBS + phase\u2010shifters so that:  \n   \u2013 Upon detecting certain click patterns on detectors D1\u2013D4, the network has enacted the SWITCH: (|0\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_B\u2009U_A + |1\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_A\u2009U_B)|\u03c8\u27e9_T in mode T_out  \n   \u2013 Simultaneously, detectors D5\u2013D8 record the outcomes needed to evaluate the causal witness  \n       W_switch = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2013 \u00bd(Symmetrized swap operators)  \n\n\u2022 Click logic:\n   \u2013 A herald on {D1\u2013D4} flags successful SWITCH execution.  \n   \u2013 Coincidences on {D5\u2013D8} yield Tr[W_switch\u2009\u03c1_{C,T_out}]; a negative value certifies genuine superposition of orders.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Quantum\u2010SWITCH plus integrated causal\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'Switch_CausalWitness',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['11001100','00110011'],  # abstract labels for witness & herald subspace\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,2],[1,3]],         # forbid direct control-target paths\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and expandable:\n\u2022 It elevates indefinite causal order from \u201cproduce and then verify\u201d to a single fused network primitive\u2014distribution of superposed gate\u2010orders and their built\u2010in certification.  \n\u2022 By choosing different U_A,U_B or different causal witnesses, one obtains a family of \u201cprocess\u2010switch+certify\u201d modules for photonic quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Entirely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract targets, static linear optics, pair\u2010sources, single\u2010photon ancillas, and no dynamic feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While merging a quantum\u2010SWITCH implementation and its causal\u2010witness test into one static interferometer is a neat integration, both the photonic quantum switch (see \u201cPhotonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\u201d) and linear-optical causal-witness measurements are already established. Simply combining them into a larger post-selected circuit does not yield a fundamentally new joint\u2010measurement primitive or reveal an unexpected interference effect that can\u2019t be decomposed into separate SWITCH and witness modules.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both the SWITCH gadget and the causal-witness projector exist in the literature. To reach PRL-level novelty, you\u2019d need an inseparable joint projector or a genuinely new quantum-network phenomenon emerging only when the two are fused, not just a pipelined integration.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cMonogamy\u2010Witness Swap Network\u201d as a new Pytheus target. One static linear\u2010optical circuit that\u2014with two EPR\u2010pair sources and two ancilla photons\u2014simultaneously:\n  (i) Performs entanglement swapping at node B (mixing modes B and C) to deliver an A\u2013C link,\n  (ii) Runs two overlapping CHSH entanglement witnesses on pairs A\u2013B and A\u2013C in the very same network.\n\nStructure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n  \u2022 Sources:\n      S\u2081 \u2192 modes A,B  \n      S\u2082 \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  (we identify B\u2032\u2261B for swapping)  \n  \u2022 Ancillas: photons in modes E,F  \n  \u2022 Multiport U mixes B, B\u2032, E, F with appropriate beam splitters & phases.\n  \u2022 Detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085:\n      \u2013 A subset of coincidences on {D\u2080,D\u2081} and {D\u2082,D\u2083} herald the Bell\u2010measurement at B (successful swap).\n      \u2013 Coincidences on {D\u2084,D\u2085} vs {D\u2080,D\u2082} yield the four correlation outcomes needed for CHSH_AB.\n      \u2013 Coincidences on {D\u2081,D\u2083} vs {D\u2084,D\u2085} yield the four correlation outcomes for CHSH_AC.\n\nFrom the three simultaneous correlation datasets one computes \u27e8CHSH_AB\u27e9 and \u27e8CHSH_AC\u27e9. Their squared sum obeys the monogamy bound \u27e8CHSH_AB\u27e9\u00b2 + \u27e8CHSH_AC\u27e9\u00b2 \u2264 8. A violation of classical trade\u2010offs directly certifies polygamous nonlocality in a single experiment.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description':  \n    'Entanglement\u2010swap between AB & BC with integrated CHSH_AB and CHSH_AC witnesses',\n  'foldername': 'Swap_Monogamy_Witness',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_patterns': ['1010','0101'],   # abstract labels for the two CHSH witness subspaces\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3]],       # forbid direct A\u2013C source\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 Introduces a new fused\u2010network primitive: swap+dual\u2010witness measurement probing entanglement monogamy/polygamy.  \n  \u2022 By adding more sources (e.g. 3 links) or changing the witness (GHZ\u2010type), one obtains a family of multi\u2010node \u201cswap+witness\u201d analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s design domain: abstract targets (swap projector \u2297 two CHSH projectors), linear optics, ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This \u201cMonogamy\u2010Witness Swap Network\u201d merely pipelines two well\u2010known linear\u2010optical modules\u2014entanglement swapping at B and CHSH\u2010type entanglement witnesses on A\u2013B and A\u2013C\u2014into one larger interferometer. There is no genuinely new joint projector or interference effect that intrinsically couples swap and dual\u2010witness measurements into an inseparable primitive; it remains decomposable into separate swap + witness operations.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Entanglement swapping and static CHSH witness circuits have been thoroughly explored. Simply integrating dual CHSH tests with a swap in one post\u2010selected network is an incremental engineering step rather than a novel quantum\u2010network measurement primitive. To reach PRL\u2010level novelty, you\u2019d need a fused measurement that cannot be broken into independent swap and witness blocks or an unexpected quantum effect emerging only in the combined scheme.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose a \u201cBell\u2013CHSH Fused POVM Analyzer.\u201d\n\nDescription:\n One static linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133) plus two ancilla photons (modes 4\u20135)\u2014realizes in one go:\n  \u2022 A partial Bell\u2010state projection (entanglement swapping between the pairs)  \n  \u2022 The negative\u2010subspace projector of the CHSH entanglement witness on the same two modes.\n\nKey feature:\n \u2022 Two click\u2010patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 on the six output detectors simultaneously signal \u201cswap success\u201d and give the two anti\u2010correlated CHSH outcomes.  \n \u2022 Both tasks emerge from the same optimized unitary U; you cannot decompose it into separate swap and witness blocks.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:\n    S\u2081\u2192 modes 0,1  \n    S\u2082\u2192 modes 2,3  \n  Ancillas: photons in modes 4,5  \n  Interferometer U mixes modes [0\u20265] via beam splitters & phases  \n  Detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085 record 6\u2010bit patterns;  \n    \u2013 P\u2081 = \u201c100100\u201d heralds Bell\u2010swap success + CHSH outcome +1  \n    \u2013 P\u2082 = \u201c011010\u201d heralds Bell\u2010swap success + CHSH outcome \u20131  \n  All other patterns are discarded.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Fused Bell\u2010projection & CHSH\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'Bell_CHSH_Fused',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['100100','011010'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting & expandable:\n \u2022 Defines a new photonic \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d primitive: entanglement distribution (swap) and certification (witness) fused into one measurement.  \n \u2022 By swapping in different witnesses (GHZ, qudit\u2010CHSH) or different partial Bell projections (higher\u2010D swapping), one generates a family of \u201cfused\u2010POVM\u201d network experiments.  \n \u2022 Entirely in Pytheus\u2019s domain: abstract target patterns, linear optics, ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state generation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This proposal merely pipelines two well\u2010known linear\u2010optical modules\u2014partial Bell\u2010state projection (entanglement swapping) and a CHSH entanglement\u2010witness measurement\u2014into one larger interferometer, without introducing a genuinely new joint projector or unexpected interference effect that cannot be decomposed into separate swap and witness steps. It remains an incremental engineering integration rather than a novel quantum\u2010network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Both partial Bell projections and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement\u2010witness circuits are established. Stitching them into a single 6-mode multiport whose click patterns serve both roles does not create a fundamentally new measurement operator or reveal a nontrivial quantum effect. To reach PRL novelty you would need an inseparable fused POVM that cannot be split into independent swap and witness blocks or an unexpected resource advantage emerging only in the combined scheme."
}

Specific coincidence patterns on detectors O\u2013R yield a direct estimate of Tr[W\u2009\u03c1_{AF}].  \n - Heralding: a joint detection on G\u2013L confirms swapping, simultaneous detections on O\u2013R yield the witness outcome. A negative witness value (below threshold) certifies genuine 3-D entanglement on A\u2013F.  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:  \n - It unifies two key primitives\u2014high-D entanglement distribution and one-shot entanglement certification\u2014into a single linear-optical network that Pytheus can optimize.  \n - The same architecture scales to higher dimensions (ququarts, qudits) by increasing the number of inputs and ancilla, and to different witness operators by adjusting which coincidence patterns are targeted.  \n - It opens the door to integrated \u201centanglement\u2010delivery\u2010and\u2010proof\u201d modules in future quantum networks, without requiring cavities, feedback, or non\u2010linear elements.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both qutrit swapping and linear-optical entanglement\u2010witness circuits have been previously demonstrated. A generalized Bell\u2010measurement on modes C and D (the middle photons) that, upon a heralding click pattern, entangles the remote photons A and F (entanglement swapping).\n  2. In the very same optical circuit and detection event, projects modes A and F (together with two fresh ancilla) onto the basis elements of a chosen entanglement witness W, so that the click pattern state then separately verify\u201d to a unified \u201cone\u2010shot distribute+certify\u201d primitive.  \n  \u2022 By changing the dimension of sources (qutrits \u2192 ququarts) or choosing different CHSH\u2010Witness Subblock:\n   \u2022 In the same optical layout (no reconfiguration), the surviving photons in modes A,D and ancillas F,G are mixed by U\u2082  \n   \u2022 Detectors D4\u2013D7 record the four relevant coincidence patterns corresponding to the \u22121 eigenvalues of the CHSH witness operator\n       W_CHSH = 2\u00b7I \u2013 (X\u2297X + X\u2297Z + Z\u2297X \u2013 Z\u2297Z).\n   \u2022 From their frequencies one directly computes Tr[W_CHSH\u2009\u03c1_{AD}].\n\nTopology constraint:\n   \u2022 removed_connections = [[A,D],[B,C]] to forbid any direct source linking senders with wrong receivers.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Butterfly quantum network coding + CHSH witness fused analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'QNC_CHSH_Witness',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['0101','1010'],    # bit\u2010strings for CHSH \u22121 outcomes on A/D vs ancillas\n  'single_emitters': [],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting and expandable:\n \u2022 Defines a new primitive: execute a nontrivial quantum\u2010network algorithm (butterfly entanglement routing) and certify the resulting entanglement in a single nonadaptive measurement.\n \u2022 Swapping in other small network algorithms (3\u2010node coding, qudit \u201cbutterfly\u201d) and other witnesses (GHZ, qudit CHSH) yields a rich family of \u201calgorithm\u2009+\u2009certification\u201d modules.\n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities: abstract target (swap + witness projectors), static linear optics, ancilla photons, and detectors\u2014no state generation or feedback.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both the butterfly entanglement routing and the CHSH\u2010type entanglement witness are established static linear\u2010optical modules. Heralding detectors D1\u2013D4 click pattern flags that R_z(\u03c0/2) has been applied to the unknown input In\u2081, now in mode Out.  \n    \u2013 Stage 2: Without reconfiguration, U\u2081\u2019s remaining interferometric mesh routes In\u2081 and Out photons (plus Anc\u2081 re\u2010injected) into the same device to implement the CHSH\u2010witness projector.  \n2) Simultaneously projects the joint control\u2013target quantum onto the causal\u2010nonseparability witness W_switch, whose negative expectation certifies indefinite causal order.\n\nExperiment sketch (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n\u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2081 emits an EPR pair into modes C\u2080,C\u2081 (control qubit)  \n   \u2013 Pair\u2010source S\u2082 emits an EPR pair into modes T\u2080,T\u2081 (target qubit)  \n\n\u2022 Ancilla:  \n   \u2013 Two single\u2010photon ancillas in modes A\u2080,A\u2081 to enlarge the interferometer for the witness measurement  \n\n\u2022 Static multiport U mixes modes {C\u2081,T\u2080,A\u2080,A\u2081} via beam\u2010splitters + PBS + phase\u2010shifters so that:  \n   \u2013 Upon detecting certain click patterns on detectors D1\u2013D4, the network has enacted the SWITCH: (|0\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_B\u2009U_A + |1\u27e9_C\u2009\u2297U_A\u2009U_B)|\u03c8\u27e9_T in mode T_out  \n   \u2013 Simultaneously, detectors D5\u2013D8 record the outcomes needed to evaluate the causal witness  \n       W_switch = \u03b1\u00b7I \u2013 \u00bd(Symmetrized swap operators)  \n\n\u2022 Click logic:\n   \u2013 A herald on {D1\u2013D4} flags successful SWITCH execution.  \n   \u2013 Coincidences on {D5\u2013D8} yield Tr[W_switch\u2009\u03c1_{C,T_out}]; This directly tests the monogamy trade\u2010off P\u2081\u00b2 + P\u2082\u00b2 \u2264 8 in a single fused analyzer\u2014never done in Pytheus.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: Requires two EPR sources (AB and BC), two single\u2010photon ancillas, a beam\u2010splitter/phase\u2010shifter multiport mixing modes B,C and ancillas, and number\u2010resolving detectors. Pytheus can optimize the unitary so that certain detector\u2010coincidence subsets give CHSH_AB and CHSH_AC values while simultaneously performing the swapping.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cMonogamy\u2010Witness Swap Network\u201d as a new Pytheus target. One static linear\u2010optical circuit that\u2014with two EPR\u2010pair sources and two ancilla photons\u2014simultaneously:\n  (i) Performs entanglement swapping at node B (mixing modes B and C) to deliver an A\u2013C link,\n  (ii) Runs two overlapping CHSH entanglement witnesses on pairs A\u2013B and A\u2013C in the very same network.\n\nStructure (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n  \u2022 Sources:\n      S\u2081 \u2192 modes A,B  \n      S\u2082 \u2192 modes B\u2032,C  (we identify B\u2032\u2261B for swapping)  \n  \u2022 Ancillas: photons in modes E,F  \n  \u2022 Multiport U mixes B, B\u2032, E, F with appropriate beam splitters & phases.\n  \u2022 Detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085:\n      \u2013 A subset of coincidences on {D\u2080,D\u2081} and {D\u2082,D\u2083} herald the Bell\u2010measurement at B (successful swap).\n      \u2013 Coincidences on {D\u2084,D\u2085} vs {D\u2080,D\u2082} yield the four correlation outcomes needed for CHSH_AB.\n      \u2013 Coincidences on {D\u2081,D\u2083} vs {D\u2084,D\u2085} yield the four correlation outcomes for CHSH_AC.\n\nFrom the three simultaneous correlation datasets one computes \u27e8CHSH_AB\u27e9 and \u27e8CHSH_AC\u27e9. Their squared sum obeys the monogamy bound \u27e8CHSH_AB\u27e9\u00b2 + \u27e8CHSH_AC\u27e9\u00b2 \u2264 8. A violation of classical trade\u2010offs directly certifies polygamous nonlocality in a single experiment.\n\nPytheus\u2010style config skeleton:\n{\n  'description':  \n    'Entanglement\u2010swap between AB & BC with integrated CHSH_AB and CHSH_AC witnesses',\n  'foldername': 'Swap_Monogamy_Witness',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_patterns': ['1010','0101'],   # abstract labels for the two CHSH witness subspaces\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3]],       # forbid direct A\u2013C source\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 Introduces a new fused\u2010network primitive: swap+dual\u2010witness measurement probing entanglement monogamy/polygamy.  \n  \u2022 By adding more sources (e.g. 3 links) or changing the witness (GHZ\u2010type), one obtains a family of multi\u2010node \u201cswap+witness\u201d analyzers.  \n  \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s design domain: abstract targets (swap projector \u2297 two CHSH projectors), linear optics, ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Entanglement swapping and static CHSH witness circuits have been thoroughly explored. Simply integrating dual CHSH tests with a swap in one post\u2010selected network is an incremental engineering step rather than a novel quantum\u2010network measurement primitive. To reach PRL\u2010level novelty, you\u2019d need a fused measurement that cannot be broken into independent swap and witness blocks or an unexpected quantum effect emerging only in the combined scheme.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: We need a genuinely fused measurement primitive\u2014one device whose single interferometer and detector array realize two conceptually different projectors (Bell swap and CHSH witness) inextricably interwoven, so you cannot split the network into \u201cswap\u2010block\u201d + \u201cwitness\u2010block.\u201d  \n  Step 2: The idea is a \u201cBell\u2013CHSH Fused POVM Analyzer.\u201d It takes two Bell\u2010pair sources plus two ancillas, passes all four input photons through one optimized multiport, and yields two distinct click patterns P\u2081,P\u2082. Pattern P\u2081 both heralds entanglement swapping (Bell projection) and gives the outcome for one CHSH setting; pattern P\u2082 does the same for the complementary CHSH setting. The two patterns share all beam splitters and phases and interfere globally\u2014no separate modules.  \n  Step 3: Novel because no prior Pytheus target defines a single static linear\u2010optical network that simultaneously implements a partial Bell measurement and the negative\u2010subspace projector of a CHSH\u2010witness in one inseparable device.  \n  Step 4: Feasible in Pytheus: only uses abstract pair sources, ancilla photons, beam splitters, phase shifters, number\u2010resolving detectors; no feedback, no forbidden state generation.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cBell\u2013CHSH Fused POVM Analyzer.\u201d\n\nDescription:\n One static linear\u2010optical network that\u2014starting from two independent Bell\u2010pair sources (modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133) plus two ancilla photons (modes 4\u20135)\u2014realizes in one go:\n  \u2022 A partial Bell\u2010state projection (entanglement swapping between the pairs)  \n  \u2022 The negative\u2010subspace projector of the CHSH entanglement witness on the same two modes.\n\nKey feature:\n \u2022 Two click\u2010patterns P\u2081,P\u2082 on the six output detectors simultaneously signal \u201cswap success\u201d and give the two anti\u2010correlated CHSH outcomes.  \n \u2022 Both tasks emerge from the same optimized unitary U; you cannot decompose it into separate swap and witness blocks.\n\nVisualization (modes flow top\u2192bottom):\n  Sources:\n    S\u2081\u2192 modes 0,1  \n    S\u2082\u2192 modes 2,3  \n  Ancillas: photons in modes 4,5  \n  Interferometer U mixes modes [0\u20265] via beam splitters & phases  \n  Detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085 record 6\u2010bit patterns;  \n    \u2013 P\u2081 = \u201c100100\u201d heralds Bell\u2010swap success + CHSH outcome +1  \n    \u2013 P\u2082 = \u201c011010\u201d heralds Bell\u2010swap success + CHSH outcome \u20131  \n  All other patterns are discarded.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Fused Bell\u2010projection & CHSH\u2010witness analyzer',\n  'foldername': 'Bell_CHSH_Fused',\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 15,\n  'target_patterns': ['100100','011010'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s exciting & expandable:\n \u2022 Defines a new photonic \u201calgorithm+certification\u201d primitive: entanglement distribution (swap) and certification (witness) fused into one measurement.  \n \u2022 By swapping in different witnesses (GHZ, qudit\u2010CHSH) or different partial Bell projections (higher\u2010D swapping), one generates a family of \u201cfused\u2010POVM\u201d network experiments.  \n \u2022 Entirely in Pytheus\u2019s domain: abstract target patterns, linear optics, ancillas, number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback, no cavities, no forbidden state generation.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: Both partial Bell projections and static CHSH\u2010type entanglement\u2010witness circuits are established. Stitching them into a single 6-mode multiport whose click patterns serve both roles does not create a fundamentally new measurement operator or reveal a nontrivial quantum effect. To reach PRL novelty you would need an inseparable fused POVM that cannot be split into independent swap and witness blocks or an unexpected resource advantage emerging only in the combined scheme.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three fusions of \u201ccomplex quantum algorithm\u201d + \u201centanglement witness\u201d in a single static Pytheus network:\n    1) Indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order SWITCH + causal\u2010nonseparability witness  \n    2) Teleportation\u2010gate (CNOT or phase) + channel (Choi) entanglement witness  \n    3) Channel\u2010discrimination algorithm (decide U\u2080 vs U\u2081 using an entangled probe) + Choi\u2010state entanglement witness  \n  Step 2: Check novelty & feasibility:\n    \u2013 (1) and (2) both decompose into known modules and have been conceptually proposed; Pytheus can do each separately and even pipelined but that isn\u2019t a new irreducible primitive.  \n    \u2013 (3) No Pytheus target so far asks for one static interferometer whose click\u2010patterns simultaneously discriminate between two candidate unitaries AND certify the entanglement of the corresponding Choi state via a witness. It uses only probabilistic pair\u2010sources, ancilla photons, beam\u2010splitters/phases, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014exactly Pytheus\u2019s design domain.  \n  Step 3: Select idea (3).  \n  Step 4: Novelty: It defines a single POVM whose outcomes both guess which unitary was applied and witness the Choi\u2010state entanglement. You cannot split the network into separate discrimination\u2010and\u2010then\u2010witness; the same optimized multiport effects both tasks.  \n  Step 5: Feasibility: Pytheus can optimize the joint projector defined by two target click\u2010patterns (one for \u201cU\u2080\u2009& entangled,\u201d one for \u201cU\u2081\u2009& entangled\u201d), using only static linear optics and ancillas, with no feedback or forbidden hardware.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose a \u201cFused Channel\u2010Discrimination + Choi\u2010Witness Analyzer.\u201d  \n\nExplanation:\n \u2022 Task: Two unknown candidate unitaries U\u2080 and U\u2081 act on one half of an entangled pair. We wish in a single static linear\u2010optical network to both (a) decide which unitary was applied (channel discrimination algorithm) and (b) certify that the joint input\u2013output (Choi) state is entangled by evaluating a two\u2010qubit entanglement witness.  \n \u2022 Setup:  \n   \u2013 Probabilistic Bell\u2010pair S\u2081 \u2192 modes 0,1 (0 is reference, 1 goes through unknown U\u2093).  \n   \u2013 Probabilistic Bell\u2010pair S\u2082 \u2192 modes 2,3 (2 is reference, 3 goes through the same U\u2093).  \n   \u2013 Two ancilla single photons \u2192 modes 4,5.  \n \u2022 Multiport: A single unitary U mixes modes 0\u20135 via beam splitters and phase shifters.  \n \u2022 Detectors: Six number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2080\u2026D\u2085 record clicks.  \n   \u2013 Pattern P\u2080 = \u201c110011\u201d heralds \u201cU\u2080 was applied\u201d AND Choi\u2010witness outcome \u2018entangled.\u2019  \n   \u2013 Pattern P\u2081 = \u201c001100\u201d heralds \u201cU\u2081\u2009was applied\u201d AND Choi\u2010witness outcome \u2018entangled.\u2019  \n   \u2013 All other patterns are discarded.  \n \u2022 The same interference that directs amplitude into P\u2080 vs. P\u2081 simultaneously enforces discrimination and entanglement\u2010witness projectors\u2014no separate modules.\n\nPytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Fused discrimination of U0/U1 plus Choi\u2010state entanglement witness',\n  'foldername': 'Disc_ChoiWitness',\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-06,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 2,\n  'samples': 12,\n  'target_quantum': ['110011','001100'],\n  'removed_connections': [[0,3],[1,2]],  # forbid any direct 0\u21923 or 1\u21922 links\n  'number_resolving': True\n}\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 Introduces a new irreducible network primitive: one static multiport performing both a channel\u2010discrimination algorithm and an entanglement\u2010witness measurement in a single POVM.  \n \u2022 By replacing U\u2080/U\u2081 with other channel sets or choosing different witness operators (e.g. multipartite Choi witnesses), you generate a broad family of \u201cdiscriminate\u2009+\u2009certify\u201d quantum\u2010network modules.  \n \u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s framework: only abstract pair sources, linear optics, ancilla photons, and photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014no feedback or forbidden state engineering."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Swap-and-Concentrate Repeater for Heralded |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 Bell Pairs\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a single-step quantum repeater node that simultaneously swaps and concentrates two non-maximally entangled SPDC links into a heralded maximally entangled Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 between remote modes. By statically mixing the inner modes in an optimized linear-optics network and post-selecting on two threshold-detector clicks, the scheme realizes the target Bell pair in one heralded operation without active feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nSymmetry-Protected Bound-State Router for Heralded Bell-State Generation in a Three-Node Quantum Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe employ a C\u2083-symmetric tritter to engineer a symmetry-protected bound state in the continuum (BIC) that traps an intermediate photon until a three\u2010fold no-click heralding event triggers entanglement swapping between remote nodes. Conditioned on this herald, the protocol projects the target two-photon Bell state onto modes A and D using only static linear optics and photon-number\u2013resolving detection, demonstrating a programmable route for scalable entanglement distribution.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Hybrid-Dimensional Qubit\u2013Qutrit Entanglement Swapping via a Full 2\u00d73 Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in PyTheus a probabilistic protocol that entangles a Rydberg-encoded qubit (mode 0) with a condensate-encoded qutrit (mode 3) by performing a full 2\u00d73 Bell measurement on a shared qubit\u2013qutrit mediator (modes 1&2).  Conditioned on one of the six generalized Bell outcomes, this linear-optics and number-resolving detection scheme heralds the target qubit\u2013qutrit Bell state \u201600\u27e9+ei\u03c6\u201612\u27e9/\u221a2 across the two distinct Hilbert spaces without feedback, hyper-entanglement, or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Non-Destructive QND Measurement of Photon-Number Difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND via Mode-Squeezed Ancillas\n\nMini-Abstract: We introduce a PyTheus network primitive that non-destructively measures the photon-number difference \u0394N = NA \u2013 ND between two distant Fock-encoded modes A and D by mixing each with one arm of a two-mode squeezed ancilla at static beam splitters and post-selecting on the ancilla detector difference outcome k. This scheme infers the target \u0394N without disturbing modes A and D, providing a distributed QND observable extraction for syndrome readout and error checking across network nodes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Entanglement-Dimension Adapter for d\u21922 Bell State Conversion\n\nMini-abstract: We design a linear-optical network that probabilistically compresses a d-dimensional Bell pair emitted by a Kerr resonator and a two-level Bell pair from a transmon into the canonical two-qubit Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9 across modes A\u2081 (node 0) and B\u2082 (node 3). By mixing modes A\u2082 and B\u2081 with ancilla photons in an optimized interferometer and employing photon-number-resolving detection, the scheme heralds successful swapping and compression of multi-level entanglement into a qubit link between the Kerr and transmon nodes without feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Blockade-Assisted Entanglement Purification of Noisy Bell Pairs\n\nAbstract: We introduce a static linear-optical protocol that combines two probabilistic noisy Bell-pair sources with single-emitter photon-blockade nodes to suppress double-pair emissions and distill the target high-fidelity Bell state |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9=(|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9)/\u221a2. By performing a parity check on one photon from each pair via a 50:50 beam splitter and enforcing \u22641-photon inputs through photon-blockade ancillae, specific heralding detection patterns project the remaining photons onto the purified Bell state within the PyTheus framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive Linear-Optical 4D Bell-State Analyzer for Frequency-Encoded Photonic Ququarts\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a fully passive, post-selected linear-optical network that combines dielectric photonic-crystal spectral demultiplexers with a metasurface-fabricated 10\u00d710 multiport interferometer to unambiguously discriminate the four generalized Bell states of two photonic ququarts, each encoded in four narrowband frequency bins. In the current experiment, the explicit target is to herald each of the four Bell-state outcomes using two ancilla photons and ten number-resolving detectors\u2014realizing, for the first time, a high-dimensional Bell-state analyzer to enable ququart teleportation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Flux\u2010Controlled Chiral Teleportation Routing in a Hermitian Topological Ring\n\nAbstract: We propose a static, linear\u2010optical experiment that implements a chiral teleportation router on a Hermitian one\u2010dimensional periodic lattice of three nodes, injecting a single\u2010photon qubit at node A and performing Bell measurements on edges AB, BC, and CA. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Conditioned on a heralding four-fold click at the central router, the scheme probabilistically produces the target quantum\u2014two remote Bell pairs |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{A,C} \u2297 |\u03a6\u207a\u3009_{B,D}\u2014while halving the ancilla and measurement overhead of standard approaches.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded CPHASE\u2010Gate Sensor for Nonlinear Product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B Detection\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate a heralded linear-optical protocol that entangles two remote static phase shifts \u03c6_A and \u03c6_B via an ancilla-assisted CPHASE gate, imprinting the nonlinear product cos\u2009\u03c6_A\u00b7cos\u2009\u03c6_B into the conditioned joint click probability. By calibrating and subtracting the individual cos\u2009\u03c6_A and cos\u2009\u03c6_B fringes, the scheme isolates the target phase product \u03c6_A\u00b7\u03c6_B and attains near-Heisenberg scaling in Fisher information with full loss tolerance.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Multi-Frequency GHZ Entanglement Swapping for Three-Node Quantum Networks\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an on-chip multi-frequency entanglement-swapping protocol that projects three frequency-encoded qubits onto the GHZ basis, thereby distributing genuine tripartite GHZ entanglement among three remote nodes A, B, and C. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement-Assisted Teleported Error-Detecting Channel (EAQECC-Teleport)\n\nAbstract: We implement a linear-optical network that realizes the target transformation\u2014teleporting a logical qubit from sender A to receiver D while detecting any single-photon erasure\u2014by embedding a (3,1) entanglement-assisted quantum error-detecting code across two relay nodes B and C.
